Posts.EditableText:
Well...friends and myself sometimes play Dungeons and Dragons, and recently I created a massive quest that involves a lot of puzzle opening and key finding and people convincing.  Anyway, with as much thought as I put into it, I thought that I could try my hand at making it into a computer game.  Though how to start is one thing...putting it together is another.  Now in DnD, there is monster fighting and leveling up, which I am not interested at all in adding to this at this point, but creating a world of oddities I am.  

Locked boxes within locked boxes, citizens who need to be "persuaded" to give you information, large mechanical dragons and deep wells you have to climb down...that sort of thing.  I don't want the player to get to die...at least not right now...so say the player will need to either find, barter, or buy a good sturdy rope and figure out how to attach it, before they can go climbing down the well...stuff like that.

At least this is the idea at hand.
Posts.HTML:
Well...friends and myself sometimes play Dungeons and Dragons, and recently I created a massive quest that involves a lot of puzzle opening and key finding and people convincing. Anyway, with as much thought as I put into it, I thought that I could try my hand at making it into a computer game. Though how to start is one thing...putting it together is another. Now in DnD, there is monster fighting and leveling up, which I am not interested at all in adding to this at this point, but creating a world of oddities I am.

Locked boxes within locked boxes, citizens who need to be "persuaded" to give you information, large mechanical dragons and deep wells you have to climb down...that sort of thing. I don't want the player to get to die...at least not right now...so say the player will need to either find, barter, or buy a good sturdy rope and figure out how to attach it, before they can go climbing down the well...stuff like that.

At least this is the idea at hand.

Posts.EditableText:
Thanks....I tell ya if I need them.

  I am thinking that I want to try and make the game as emersable as possible.  That when a player goes into a room with a description like '...and the walls are covered in peeling green wallpaper...' that if you choose to look at the wallpaper, you won't get a messabel that there is no wallpaper to look at or that all you can do is look at it considering it is just a scenery object, but be able to tear off a piece if you want, or color on it with a crayon (if you find one), or anything that you think of.  Though I don't want to go to far, or else one room might take me a year.

Posts.EditableText: Well I have no idea what ASL scripting is...I am trying to use the QDK system.  Is it easier to script?
Posts.HTML: Well I have no idea what ASL scripting is...I am trying to use the QDK system.  Is it easier to script?

Posts.EditableText:
[quote="scobert":17kzibci]Well I have no idea what ASL scripting is...I am trying to use the QDK system.  Is it easier to script?[/quote:17kzibci]
The .asl files contain the scripts.  The QDK program generates those scripts.  Some people prefer to script instead of using QDK, as it does give you better control over your content.  QDK may also produce bugs which generate errors in the script, so it's handy to know some basic ASL in order to fix those problems.

But it's not rocket science, it just takes time to sit down and read the help document, and learn it as you go along, something which I should have done myself.
Posts.HTML:
scobert wrote:Well I have no idea what ASL scripting is...I am trying to use the QDK system. Is it easier to script?

The .asl files contain the scripts. The QDK program generates those scripts. Some people prefer to script instead of using QDK, as it does give you better control over your content. QDK may also produce bugs which generate errors in the script, so it's handy to know some basic ASL in order to fix those problems.

But it's not rocket science, it just takes time to sit down and read the help document, and learn it as you go along, something which I should have done myself.
